title: How long to wait before filing for bankcruptcy?
question: I have a medical debt which I am not able to pay. The creditors have said that if this is not paid within the next 10 days it will be sent to collection. I have some savings ($35,000) but it is not enough to pay the debt & I know that if I make a settlement for less than I owe that I will get a 1099 & still be unable to pay. My debt is around $93,000. I don't own any property but have about $10,000 in stock, a 401K plan, life insurance & about $4,300 in mutual funds. Can I loose all this money if I file BK. I do qualify for Chapter 7. Income is around $42,000 with a family of 3. Should I wait at least an year before filing or should I start the proceedings right away.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,State, local, and municipal law
answers:
In your case, you should speak with a Bankruptcy attorney in your area to begin Bankruptcy planning right away. If you filed without planning, you could lose a substantial portion of your cash assets, stocks and possibly the mutual funds. In California, the personal exemption is about $22,000 plus certain exemptions for personal property. Qualified retirement plans are exempt from the Trustee's reach. Life insurance is usually exempt unless there is a cash payout of more than about $13K.

Again, you are strongly urged to call a local Bankruptcy attorney to discuss your case.

Scott Jordan

You need to contact an attorney and make sure all your assets can be protected. Most offices will offer a free consultation and make that determination when you come in for your appointment. Another important consideration is whether or not your medical situation is now resolved.

I say this to literally everyone that calls my office... the key to an appropriate bankruptcy filing is proper bankruptcy planning. The important thing is not to file prematurely. You file when you have appropriately planned your bankruptcy filing.

Hope that helps.

Feel free to contact me for a free 20 minute consultation if you would like further help.

You would benefit from some valid, allwable bankruptcy planning which is a bit beyond the scope of this great website. I urge you to find an experienced bankruptcy practitioner nearby.

Whether or not bankruptcy filers can keep any individual asset depends on many factors, including how much property is owned and what exemptions are available to cover the property. Even though bankruptcy law is federal, the question of whether and what assets are protected by exemptions requires analysis in view of state law.

Bankruptcy requires complete review of your entire financial situation including all debts, income and assets. I highly recommend that you seek representation from an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your jurisdiction to guide you through the complexities of bankruptcy law and procedure.

This answer is provided for informational purposes only. Actual legal advice can only be provided in an office consultation by an attorney licensed in your jurisdiction, with experience in the area of law in which your concern lies.
